document.title: Utah Core State Standards for Social Studies 2017

D908FC69DAA144E385569171CDF2D6B0.description:
Students will craft an argument for an appropriate role for the
United States to take in addressing a global economic, environmental,
or social issue such as humanitarian aid, migration,
pandemics, or the loss of wildlife habitat.

C1DB5CB3F51B4F21A9A3EC994287D048.description:
Students will evaluate how global economic interdependence
and international trade policies affect the economy of the United
States.

D7336028A41F48248A838E05DF5A5E99.description:
Students will analyze the justification for, and effectiveness of,
specific foreign policy positions, such as military intervention,
isolationism, alliance formation, economic sanctions, or other
security measures.

727D00C6B1274C60955234FA9AAB34FE.description:
Students will analyze the constitutional process of creating
foreign policy and the structures through which the federal
government interacts with foreign governments, such as the
Department of State, treaties, agreements, and alliances.

F046759EE61D4174884403FCC80BCA44.description: The U.S. and Our Relationship to the World

534DFCD7DD624F1A97F8AD4ED407ED9F.description:
Students will propose and defend budget priorities at either the
local, state, tribal, or federal level; and share their findings with
appropriate stakeholders.

3636EF855FD24E48A6188D7AA765D3B9.description:
Students will explain how government services and other budget
priorities are funded through various forms of revenue
streams, such as fees, bonding, and regressive and progressive
taxes, including property taxes, income taxes, and sales taxes.

3D0798FA695044EF92F551F5489697DA.description:
Students will examine the fiscal decisions governmental agencies
must make and the economic philosophies that guide those
decisions.

A183686A77A74275A20497E8947DBDFB.description:
Students will explain how the administrative rulemaking process
functions within the federal system and the extent and impact of
these rules.

8C59E5D38EE842E3B9307E842C3989EE.description:
Students will explain how the individual roles of the members of
the President’s cabinet are designed to meet various purposes in
government.


AA3D6ED853804B0EB0E20B993E45FC86.description:
Students will use data to evaluate election results and explain
election processes and strategies.

68387CCAC32D41138A62882795C38A4D.description:
Students will explain the processes and motivations for how
and why people organize to participate in civic society, such
as developing political affiliations, joining political parties, and
supporting special interest groups and other non-governmental
or non-partisan civic organizations, and evaluate the political
impact of those affiliations.

7D13945142AD4DBCBFA39D69FD2739D9.description:
Students will explain the role that local elected officers fulfill,
such as mayors, council members, auditors, treasurers, surveyors,
assessors, recorders, clerks, sheriffs, county commissioners,
and district or county attorneys and how local government roles
differ from state and federal roles.

73EE720D747B4DE3AF2A061C40C92FF6.description:
Students will explain the distribution of power among national,
state, tribal, and local governments in order to identify how
needs are met by governance systems.

6A77C999EDFA44D48954341689059389.description:
Students will explain the purpose and importance of fulfilling
civic responsibilities, including serving on juries; voting; serving
on boards, councils, and commissions; remaining well-informed;
contacting elected officials; and other duties associated with
active citizenship.

C7994851525045959200CF1B080AFED4.description:
Students will examine various perspectives on a current
rights-related issue; take a position; defend that position using
the Constitution and Bill of Rights, historical precedents,
Supreme Court decisions, and other relevant resources; and
share that position, when possible, with relevant stakeholders.

2C6463039A224CAA8ECF651998EAA999.description:
Students will use historic and modern case studies, including
Supreme Court cases, amendment initiatives, and legislation to
trace the application of civil liberties, civil rights, and responsibilities
spelled out in the Constitution, the Bill of Rights, and other
amendments.

0DCE67E45CB74F559AC98B7966C029F0.description: Civil Liberties, Civil Rights, and Responsibilites

3B6370D52E5548A0BDD5701FB839BA55.description:
Students will explain the organization, functions, and processes
of the United States government, such as the purpose of the
President’s cabinet, the function of judicial review, and how a bill
becomes a law, and apply that understanding to current issues.

4E42AD114B084547A74983B9C5916200.description:
Students will explain how documents, challenges, events, and
ideas such as the rule of law, the social contract, compromise,
the Declaration of Independence, the Articles of Confederation,
Shays’ Rebellion, and the Federalist Papers significantly influenced
the United States Constitution.
